source.name: Gapminder
source.additionalInfo: Gapminder dataset. Available online at http://www.gapminder.org/.

1393.name: Total Taxes (ICTD)
1393.description: Total revenue from social contributions, direct and indirect taxes, as share of national GDP.

source.name: ICTD
source.dataPublishedBy: International Centre for Tax and Development
source.dataPublisherSource: OECD Revenue Statistics; OECD Latin American Tax Statistics; IMF Government Finance Statistics (GFS); IMF Article IV Staff Reports; CEPALSTAT Revenue Statistics in Latin America.
source.additionalInfo: This data comes from the 'merged' dataset provided by ICTD, after excluding observations flagged as unreliable. Specifically, we excluded the observations classified by ICTD as “Not Credible” or of “Questionable Analytical Comparability”. Details regarding these flags, as well as the dataset more generally, are available Prichard, W. (2016). Reassessing Tax and Development Research: A New Dataset, New Findings, and Lessons for Research. World Development, 80, 48-60.

7370.name: Government Effectiveness - wbgi_gee
7370.description: Government Effectiveness - Estimate: ''Government Effectiveness'' combines into a single grouping responses on the quality of public service provision, the quality of the bureaucracy, the competence of civil servants, the independence of the civil service from political pressures, and the credibility of the government's commitment to policies. The main focus of this index is on ''inputs'' required for the government to be able to produce and implement good policies and deliver public goods.
7370.datasetName: Quality of Government - Quality of Government dataset
7370.s_name: Worldbank via the Quality of Government dataset

source.name: Worldbank via the Quality of Government dataset
source.additionalInfo: These indicators are based on several hundred individual variables measuring perceptions of governance, drawn from 31 separate data sources constructed by 25 different organizations. These individual measures of governance are assigned to categories capturing key dimensions of governance. An unobserved component model is used to construct six aggregate governance indicators. Point estimates of the dimensions of governance, the margins of error as well as the number of sources are presented for each country. The governance estimates are normally distributed with a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one each year of measurement. This implies that virtually all scores lie between -2.5 and 2.5, with higher scores corresponding to better outcomes.\ \WARNING: Since the estimates are standardized (with a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one) each year of measurement, they are not directly suitable for over-time comparisons within countries. Kaufmann et al. (2006) however find no systematic time-trends in a selection of indicators that do allow for comparisons over time, which suggests that time-series information in the WBGI scores can be used if interpreted with caution.
